comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
"The Bangor boats away....." is a children's nursery rhyme from Belfast.

"The Bangor boats away 
We have no time to play 
We'll not go near the water 
To chase the boats away."

or 

"The Bangor boats away 
We have no time to play 
gave it a kick 
make it go quick 
The Bangor boats away"

KLOW - will be a vessel called "Wicklow" or "Arklow"

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: It is possible that the two most left hadn buildings are the east of the harbour in Bangor. The bigger building at the very edge could be what is now the Rabbit Rooms. It is a very old 4 storey building and has 4 windows along the face of it. What gives me doubt is the building to the right which has always been a hotel and although it had further storeys added to it during it's life time what I can see here does not look right. I am having a battle to get street view working perhaps someone else can?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Some of the buildings match up to those in Quay Street, but what also gives me doubt that this is Bangor is that old harbour was very shallow at this point. The steamers coming into Bangor mainly came in along an old wooden pier (the precursor to the Eisenhower's pier) that projects out west north west. It is not impossible they took the ground at this point though. In your shot [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]  you can see how shallow it is.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The photo above appears on the back cover of "In Belfast Town - 1864-1880" (Brian Walker & Hugh Dixon, Friar's Bush Press, 1984). These buildings are shown quite clearly in Lawrence's photo of the Queen Bridge (plate C2423), which appears on page 94 of "No Mean City - Belfast 1880-1914" (Brian Walker & Hugh Dixon, Friar's Bush Press, 1983). The buildings behind the Bangor Castle are Donegall Quay.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Are the boats in the two shots one and the same at all at all?  In this one the covering for the paddle wheels is semi-circular whereas in the other one one end is quite drawn out into a half teardrop shape!  In addition in Bangor Castle II there is a fitting or fairing around the base of the stacks whereas in this shot above there is no such fairing!  I would say that you are right Gerry and that this was taken in Belfast from the evidence you have adduced!

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Both appear to be the same boat. The other photo (Bangor Castle II) is clearly the "PS Bangor Castle" as can be seen from its name on the cover of the paddle. Walker & Dixon name the one above also as "PS Bangor Castle" - they identify the one behind it as "PS Erin". They source their information from "Irish Passenger Steamship Services; Volume I, North of Ireland" (DB McNeill, Newton Abbott, 1969). They say that "PS Bangor Castle" was built in 1864 by Wingate of Glasgow, the steamer began the Belfast-Bangor route in 1873. Originally called the "Palmerston", the name was changed to "Bangor Castle" in 1877 after she was re-registered in Belfast. She was sold to the Plymouth Excursion Steam Boat Co and left the lough in 1894. The "Bangor Castle" was scrapped in 1899.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: This advert appeared regularly in the belfast Newsletter between May and August 1877. It mentions both the Bangor Castle and the Erin

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Less happy times for the Bangor Castle. Alarming Accident to an Excursion Steamer (Hampshire Telegraph and Sussex Chronicle Saturday, July 30, 1887)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
A description of the Bangor Castle from the Hampshire Telegraph and Sussex Chronicle on June 30th, 1888
The name of the vessel is the Bangor Castle, and she is now lying at the Royal Pier, undergoing such repairs, cleaning &c., as are necessary to fit her for her place on the regular line of traffic. The Bangor Castle is 10ft linger than Her Majesty, and has a beam of 22ft. 6in., a spacious upper deck, a hansomely furnished saloon, dining saloon, &c., The steamer is double-funnelled, and has a pair of engnes her average speed being 12 to 13 knots. She is certificated to carry 650 passengers inside the Wight. CaptainJ. R. Short will command, Mr. D. Corke takes charge of the refreshment department, and the crew are all men employed by the Company.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] I'll be a bit pedantic here and suggest that the records of the photos say it is the same boat but the appearance is quite different.  The Bangor Castle II shot shows a fresher boat with the differences mentioned above but they also show a different paintwork.  In the Bangor Castle I shot there is no name on the covers of the paddles and their structure is quite different both in shape, design and fittings.  I could see why they might change the design and fittings but the shape would be a bit radical IMO?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Well the second one says Bangor Castle on it. I've HE'd the first one but I still can't read it. It doesn't look like Bangor Castle though.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I totally agree with you - I hadn't paid too much attention to the detail of the vessels! They are totally different boats. The other one does say "Bangor Castle", so I think we can say definitively that that one is OK. The one above - I have zoomed in as best I can but can't make out the name - but one thing I'm sure of - it doesn't say "Bangor Castle"!!!

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content:
Although, like [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02], I do not think that this vessel has the name "Bangor Castle", it is evident that there were a number of steamers with that name. Walker & Dixon state:
The first steamer to operate between Belfast and Bangor was the Greenock which arrived in Belfast in 1816. A number of trips to Bangor were organised in that year on the Greenock and later in the mid-1820s on the Bangor Castle. A regular service, however, was established only in the early 1850s.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Meanwhile, were there 2 Bangor Castles in 1889? 
From the link provided by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] and the 'Alarming Accident' story ('chartered from her owners in Belfast') I thought that the Bangor Castle had spent two summers - 1887 & 1888 - in Portsmouth and the Isle of Wight. 

And indeed in September 1887 the Belfast, Bangor and Larne Steamship Co only lists the Clandeboy and he Erin. An earlier article had said that the Clandeboy had been acquired that year to increase capacity. I assume demand had not met forecasts, hence the Bangor Castle being surplus to requirements and being shipped off to the Solent.

And in the Liverpool Mercury of Oct 3 1888, the Bangor castle (PS) is reported as having left Falmouth for Belfast. So far so good.

But what is baffling me is that throughout the summer of 1889, both the Isle of Wight ferries (in the Hampshire Telegraph) and the Belfast, Bangor and Larne steamers (in the Belfast Newsletter) list a 'Bangor Castle' among their steamers. 

On reflection I'm beginning to think that it's just a case of  no-one bothering to change the wording of the advert in the Hampshire Chronicle from one year (1888) to the next(1889). 

As you were.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: To support my belief that there are two boats and not one [sailors among you will probably cringe if these should be described as ships:-( ] There are two double mooring posts on the Bangor Castle II fore and aft of both the deck beside the paddles and on the gunwale whereas there are no posts on the deck of the Bangor Castle I but two on the gunwales!  Also there is a smaller diameter pipe rising in front of the stack on the BCII and no such pipe on the BCI.  Having said that it is not that clear on BCI as the photo is taken from the aft end of the boat!  Incidentally that is a great article [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]  the captain was a resourceful man but unlucky not to be able to save his vessel!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] There was a steamer named Bangor Castle which operated on the Clyde in the 1820s. It is mentioned twice in the Caledonian Mercury in 1827, once for picking up five crew from a grain sloop which had been upset in a violent snow squall. The crew "were relieved from their perilous situation with the most  humane promptitude". Secondly, it ferried a travel writer from Glasgow to Greenock where he boarded a vessel to take him on a tour of the Western Isles.

In 1830 to 1832 and in 1839 & 1841-1848 in its annual 'List of the Belfast Shipping',  The Belfast Newsletter lists the Bangor Castle as 'engaged in the British and coast in trade', with 19 tons register (23 tons from 1841, possibly a different vessel?) , and owned by Andrew Kennedy of Bangor.
